quiz.name: Module 2: Forward Commitment and Contingent Claim Features and Instruments
quiz.subtopic: Module 2: Forward Commitment and Contingent Claim Features and Instruments

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-Erickson-Clone01ofCFA-L1-04810
entry.itemBody: An investor buys a call for $5.75 that has a strike price of $130. If the value at expiration for this call is $17.80, the price of the underlying at expiration is closest to:

answerFeedback.6161a946-41b4-44c7-a7a6-e3981d242c00: Correct because the value or "payoff to the call buyer" at expiration is cT = Max(0,ST – X) where X is the strike price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. Given the information in the stem we get $17.80 = Max(0,ST – $130). Hence, ST =$ 130 + $17.80 = $147.80.
answerFeedback.97bde422-34f2-45e5-ae0c-930dfff0565c: Incorrect because $112.20 is the value of the underlying assuming that this was a put option instead of a call option. The "payoff to the put buyer" at expiration is pT = Max(0, X – ST), where X is the exercise price and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. Given the information in the stem we get $17.80 = Max(0,$130 – ST) which yields ST = $130 – $17.80 = $112.20. By contrast, the value or "payoff to the call buyer" at expiration is cT = Max(0,ST – X). Given the information in the stem we get $17.80 = Max(0,ST – $130). Hence, ST = 130 + 17.80﻿ = 147.80, not $112.20.
answerFeedback.b3eff54f-2c1a-421a-af2e-141daae1b334: Incorrect because $142.05 is the profit from the option position added to the strike price. It is computed as (cT – c0) + X where cT is the value of the option at expiration, c0 is the purchase price of the option and X is the strike price. Given the information in the stem we get ($17.80 – $5.75) + $130 = $142.05. By contrast, the value or "payoff to the call buyer" at expiration is cT = Max(0,ST – X) where X is the strike price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. Given the information in the stem we get $17.80 = Max(0,ST – $130). Hence, ST =$ 130 + $17.80 = $147.80, not $142.05.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04712
entry.itemBody:
A call option had the following characteristics on the date it was created:

Exercise price $20
Option premium $3

If the price of the underlying is $17 at expiration, the profit to the option holder is closest to:

answerFeedback.6f7b0f00-6f97-4944-ac48-688fe2d2842f: Correct because the profit on the call buyer is Π = Max(0,ST – X) – c0, where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the exercise price, and c0 is the call option premium paid. Hence, the profit to the call option buyer or holder is Max(0,$17 – $20) – $3 = – $3.
answerFeedback.9ef69b6e-3441-465a-8c4b-7fb510ea7695: Incorrect because $0 is the profit on a long put position: the profit to the put buyer is Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the exercise price, and p0 is the put option premium paid. Hence, the profit to the put buyer is Max(0,$20 – $17) – $3 = $3 – $3 = $0. Alternatively, this is the value or payoff to the call buyer at expiration, which is Max(0,ST – X) or Max(0,$17 - $20) = $0. By contrast, the profit to the call buyer is Π = Max(0,ST – X) – c0, where c0 is the call option premium paid. Hence, the profit to the call option buyer or holder is Max(0,$17 – $20) – $3 = – $3, not $0.
answerFeedback.c9ea97ed-e1b8-47ef-86e3-c3b19497bfe9: Incorrect because $3 is the value or payoff to the put buyer at expiration, which is pT = Max(0,X – ST), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Hence the payoff to the put buyer is Max(0,$20 – $17) = $3. Alternatively, this is also the profit to the call seller which is Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where c0 is the call option premium received. Hence, the profit to the call seller is –Max(0,$17 – $20) + $3 = $0 + $3 = $3. By contrast, the profit to the call buyer is Π = Max(0,ST – X) – c0, where c0 is the call option premium paid. Hence, the profit to the call option buyer or holder is Max(0,$17 – $20) – $3 = – $3, not $3.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07175
entry.itemBody: If ST denotes the price of the underlying at the expiration date and X is the exercise price of the option, the payoff at expiration to a call seller is best described as:

answerFeedback.a12baeea-f813-41ac-9cf0-ce23ed785213: Correct because to the seller, the value of the option at that point is ‒Max(0, ST – X), which is negative to the seller if the option is in the money and zero otherwise.
answerFeedback.bbac30e1-8a1b-4a33-9bb2-0414a4262299: Incorrect because –Max(0, X – ST) (payoff to the put seller). –Max denotes a short position and X – ST the inner value of a put option at expiration. Therefore, –Max(0, X – ST) describes the payoff to a put seller and not to a call seller.
answerFeedback.f0411a0f-388a-41ba-acb0-ec507f37f786: Incorrect because Max(0, ST – X) (payoff to the call buyer). Max denotes a long position and ST – X the inner value of a call option at expiration. Therefore, Max(0, ST – X) describes the payoff to a call buyer and not to a call seller.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00791
entry.itemBody: A call option that is sold for $4 has an exercise price of $40. If the price of the underlying is $43 at expiration, the value of the option to the seller is closest to:

answerFeedback.18ae7e11-c928-4722-bcf6-8c07fea7c363: Incorrect because the value or payoff to the call seller is equal to –cT = –Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Here the value or payoff of the call to the seller is –Max(0,$43 – $40) = –$3. Further, the profit to the call seller is equal to Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where c0 is the option price or premium paid by the call buyer to the call seller. Therefore, the profit to the call seller is –Max(0,$43 – $40) + $4 = –$3 + $4 = $1, not –$1, which is equal to a loss of $1.
answerFeedback.31335c70-3904-4eb5-a6f6-5e7546a40062: Incorrect because the value or payoff to the call seller is equal to –cT = –Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Here the value or payoff of the call to the seller is –Max(0,$43 – $40) = $–3, not $3. Further, the profit to the call seller is equal to Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where c0 is the option price or premium paid by the call buyer to the call seller. Therefore, the profit to the call seller is –Max(0,$43 – $40) + $4 = –$3 + $4 = $1, not –$1 which is equal to a loss of $1.
answerFeedback.324d100d-efbc-459e-97a0-b7548cbb8aac: Correct because the value or payoff to the call seller is equal to –cT = –Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Here the value or payoff of the call to the seller is –Max(0,$43 – $40) = –$3. Further, the profit to the call seller is equal to Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where c0 is the option price or premium paid by the call buyer to the call seller. Therefore, the profit to the call seller is –Max(0,$43 – $40) + $4 = –$3 + $4 = $1.

choices.itemBody: A. –$3, and the loss to the seller is $1.
B. –$3, and the profit to the seller is $1.
C. $3, and the loss to the seller is $1.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06695
entry.itemBody: An investor pays $5 for a European put option with an exercise price of $102. At expiration, if the price of the underlying is $100, the value of the put option is:

answerFeedback.717fd1ec-13de-4dd7-8c52-15a29748cd85: Incorrect because the value of the put option is not equal to the profit to the put buyer which is Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the put premium paid.  Therefore, the profit is equal to Max(0,X – ST) – p0 = Max(0,$102 – $100) – $5 = –$3. Instead, the value of the put option at expiration is pT = Max(0,X – ST) or Max(0,$102 – 100) = $2.
answerFeedback.a529d909-e141-4585-bd10-bb2e2d84c1e5: Correct because the payoff to the put holder is:  pT = Max(0,X – ST) where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and X is the exercise price. Therefore, the value of the put at expiration when ST = $100 and X = $102 is pT = Max(0,$102 – $100) = $2.
answerFeedback.d0ffb3a4-5fff-4c72-ae01-29d5a83e0478: Incorrect because it confuses the put option with a call option. The value to the call buyer at expiration is cT = Max(0,ST – X) or Max(0,$100 – 102) = $0, where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Instead, the value of the put option at expiration is pT = Max(0,X – ST) or Max(0,$102 – 100) = $2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05443
entry.itemBody: An American put has a strike price of ¥5,000 and expires in one year. The current price of the underlying is ¥4,200 and the risk-free rate is 2%. The maximum value of this put is:

answerFeedback.0687680e-319a-4cb4-ab1b-ffc0ba51f70b: Incorrect because ¥4,900 is the present value of X, the strike price discounted at the risk-free rate of 2%. This is wrong because the payoff to the put holder is:  pT = Max(0,X – ST)  where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and X is the exercise price. Therefore, the maximum payoff is when ST = 0 and pT = Max(0,¥5,000 – 0) = ¥5,000.
answerFeedback.9c8868bb-307c-46ee-af31-fdabeb20fde0: Correct because the payoff to the put holder is:  pT = Max(0,X – ST) where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and X is the exercise price. Therefore, the maximum payoff is when ST = 0 and pT = Max(0,¥5,000 – 0) = ¥5,000.
answerFeedback.cc776d29-2254-4deb-8459-4fd60b9e2623: Incorrect because this is the payoff of the option if the current price of the underlying did not change for the next year.  The payoff to the put holder is:  pT = Max(0,X – ST) where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and X is the exercise price. Therefore, the maximum payoff is when ST = 0 and pT = Max(0,¥5,000 – 0) = ¥5,000.

entry.title: ITEM_2019BDeriv02HFJ
entry.itemBody:
The following information relates to a put option and the underlying stock:

Stock price at expiration $85
European put strike price $78

The value of the put option to the option seller at expiration is:

answerFeedback.6c36949e-aec0-4ae2-99f3-51a9c6e02f33: Incorrect because pT = Max(0,X – ST). pT is put option value at expiration, X is European put strike price and ST is stock price at expiration. So, pT = Max($0,$78 – $85) ≠ -$7. Therefore, the value of the put option at expiration is not −$7.
answerFeedback.b5d221bc-6fbc-4557-ad18-42e5a832c757: Correct because pT = Max(0,X – ST). pT is put option value at expiration, X is European put strike price and ST is stock price at expiration. So, pT = Max($0,$78 – $85) = $0. Therefore, the value of the put option at expiration is $0.
answerFeedback.bcc04029-31f5-4397-b2ef-cda229bca018: Incorrect because pT = Max(0,X – ST). pT is put option value at expiration, X is European put strike price and ST is stock price at expiration. So, pT = Max($0,$78 – $85) ≠ $7. Therefore, the value of the put option at expiration is not $7.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08105
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, if the price of the underlying at expiration exceeds the exercise price, the option value at expiration for the seller of a put most likely is:

answerFeedback.19dff177-5e78-49d7-84ac-5c226acf4b74: Incorrect because the payoff or value at expiration to the put seller is defined as –Max(0,X – ST), where X is the exercise price and ST is the value of the underlying at expiration.  If ST exceeds X, then the value to the put seller is zero. By contrast, the payoff or value to the call seller is defined as –Max(0,ST – X), in which case the value is negative. Therefore, for ST > X, the value to the put seller is zero, and therefore greater, not less than, the value to the call seller which is negative.
answerFeedback.433118be-c83f-4851-99f5-1bfa3f8d926b: Incorrect because the payoff or value at expiration to the put seller is defined as –Max(0,X – ST), where X is the exercise price and ST is the value of the underlying at expiration. If ST exceeds X, then the value to the put seller is zero. By contrast, the payoff or value to the call seller is defined as –Max(0,ST – X), in which case the value is negative. Therefore, for ST > X, the value to the put seller is zero, and therefore greater, not equal to, the value to the call seller which is negative.
answerFeedback.b0afc0f3-345e-4dda-ab9e-98d5a2184cf7: Correct because the payoff or value at expiration to the put seller is defined as –Max(0,X – ST), where X is the exercise price and ST is the value of the underlying at expiration. If ST exceeds X, then the value to the put seller is zero. By contrast, the payoff or value to the call seller is defined as –Max(0,ST – X), in which case the value is negative. Therefore, for ST > X, the value to the put seller is zero and, therefore, greater than the value to the call seller which is negative.

choices.itemBody: A. less than the option value at expiration for the seller of a call.
B. equal to the option value at expiration for the seller of a call.
C. greater than the option value at expiration for the seller of a call.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07694
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a European put option and its underlying:

Exercise price $29
Option purchase price $2
Spot price at the time of the option purchase $28

If the price of the underlying at expiration is $27, the profit for a buyer of the put is:

answerFeedback.1d50df57-61ef-43b5-a858-37c780407621: Incorrect because it represents value or payoff at expiration to the put buyer, not profit for the put buyer. The value of payoff is pT = Max(0, X – ST), where pT is the value of the put option at expiration, X is the exercise price of the option, and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. Therefore, pT = Max(0, $29 – $27) = $2. This is not the profit, which is $0, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.
answerFeedback.2c92829d-3fad-4bbd-baba-c6117406460c: Correct because the profit for a put buyer is Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the put premium paid. Therefore, the profit is equal to Max(0,$29 – $27) – $2 = $0.
answerFeedback.87f80311-810f-4984-b411-0127576012de: Incorrect because it represents the exercise price X minus the initial underlying price S0 minus the premium paid p0, or $29 – $28 – $2= –$1. This is not the profit, which is $0, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05018
entry.itemBody:
A call option has the following characteristics:

Value of underlying at expiration $2,020
Exercise price $2,100
Call premium $80

The profit to the call seller is closest to:

answerFeedback.216ad634-6879-4932-a2c6-f63eebc76152: Incorrect because $0 represents the value or payoff to the call seller which is –cT = –Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Hence, –Max(0,$2,020 – $2,100) = $0. By contrast, the profit to call seller is Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where c0 is the call option premium. Hence, –Max(0,$2,020 – $2,100) + $80 = $80, not $0.
answerFeedback.5b114fe3-dfb8-48b9-b5a6-7a8733109b61: Incorrect because –$80 represents the profit to the call buyer which is Π = Max(0,ST – X) – c0, where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the exercise price, and c0 is the call option premium. Hence, Max(0,$2,020 – $2,100) – $80 = –$80. By contrast, the profit to call seller is Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0. Hence, –Max(0,$2,020 – $2,100) + $80 = $80, not –$80.
answerFeedback.cabb6040-3289-4414-885d-b12cf76ed00f: Correct because the profit to call seller is Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the exercise price, and c0 is the call option premium received. Hence, –Max(0,$2,020 – $2,100) + $80 = $0 + $80 = $80.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04806
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely an example of a contingent claim? A(n):

answerFeedback.91c7752c-c21f-403a-a596-aaf34de97688: Correct because another class of derivatives provides the right but not the obligation to buy or sell the underlying at a pre-determined price. Because the choice of buying or selling versus doing nothing depends on a particular random outcome, these derivatives are called contingent claims. The primary contingent claim is called an option.
answerFeedback.b5ffc445-af49-4eaa-a30b-1ec5bbb57400: Incorrect because there are two general classes of derivatives. Some provide the ability to lock in a price at which one might buy or sell the underlying. Because they force the two parties to transact in the future at a previously agreed-on price, these instruments are called forward commitments. The various types of forward commitments are called forward contracts, futures contracts, and swaps. Therefore, a futures contract is a forward commitment, not a contingent claim.
answerFeedback.c17c7c8d-b409-4e97-81e1-17e0317fe6ba: Incorrect because there are two general classes of derivatives. Some provide the ability to lock in a price at which one might buy or sell the underlying. Because they force the two parties to transact in the future at a previously agreed-on price, these instruments are called forward commitments. The various types of forward commitments are called forward contracts, futures contracts, and swaps. Therefore, a swap contract is a forward commitment, not a contingent claim.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07268
entry.itemBody: Forward contracts have:

answerFeedback.1b90254e-d590-4f7e-b201-49509093244d: Correct because futures contracts are forward contracts with standardized sizes, dates, and underlyings that trade on futures exchanges. Futures markets offer both greater liquidity and protection against loss by default (compared to forwards)] by combining contract uniformity with an organized market with rules, regulations, and a central clearing facility. Also a forward contract is an over-the-counter (OTC) derivative in which two counterparties agree that one counterparty, the buyer, will purchase an underlying from the other counterparty, the seller, in the future at a pre-agreed fixed price. As noted earlier, OTC derivatives offer greater flexibility and customization than exchange-traded derivatives (ETD), but also usually involve more counterparty risk. Therefore, forwards have more counterparty risk than futures.
answerFeedback.aef43e81-1335-4b6e-bcb6-aab60e261495: Incorrect because futures contracts are forward contracts with standardized sizes, dates, and underlyings that trade on futures exchanges. Futures markets offer both greater liquidity and protection against loss by default (compared to forwards) by combining contract uniformity with an organized market with rules, regulations, and a central clearing facility. Also a forward contract is an over-the-counter (OTC) derivative in which two counterparties agree that one counterparty, the buyer, will purchase an underlying from the other counterparty, the seller, in the future at a pre-agreed fixed price. As noted earlier, OTC derivatives offer greater flexibility and customization than exchange-traded derivatives (ETD), but also usually involve more counterparty risk. Therefore, forwards have more, not less, counterparty risk than futures.
answerFeedback.e2b5cfed-4879-436f-b9b9-75c2cfcea61e: Incorrect because futures contracts are forward contracts with standardized sizes, dates, and underlyings that trade on futures exchanges. Futures markets offer both greater liquidity and protection against loss by default (compared to forwards) by combining contract uniformity with an organized market with rules, regulations, and a central clearing facility. Also a forward contract is an over-the-counter (OTC) derivative in which two counterparties agree that one counterparty, the buyer, will purchase an underlying from the other counterparty, the seller, in the future at a pre-agreed fixed price. As noted earlier, OTC derivatives offer greater flexibility and customization than exchange-traded derivatives (ETD), but also usually involve more counterparty risk. Therefore, forwards have more, not the same level, of counterparty risk than futures.

choices.itemBody: B. the same level of counter-party risk as futures.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07457
entry.itemBody: The payoff to the seller of a forward contract at expiration is defined as the:

answerFeedback.4f234807-8a9a-4bb1-b03b-62aaec4914b7: Correct because the long is obligated to pay F0(T), for which he receives an asset worth ST. The short has the mirror image of the long. He is required to deliver the asset worth ST and accept a smaller amount, F0(T). Here F0(T) is the forward price agreed at contract initiation with T denoting the time of expiry, and ST is the value of the underlying at expiry. Therefore, the payoff to the forward seller at expiration is F0(T) − ST.
answerFeedback.aaa5f9d3-cc1a-4e4b-b030-a2d7b17b21d0: Incorrect because the long is obligated to pay F0(T) for which he receives an asset worth ST. The short has the mirror image of the long. He is required to deliver the asset worth ST and accept a smaller amount, F0(T). Therefore, the payoff to the seller at expiration is F0(T) − ST, not F0(T) + ST.
answerFeedback.de13e215-79a0-496f-b205-9f1ed6d4682d: Incorrect because it represents ST − F0(T) which is the payoff for the buyer of the contract. This is not the payoff to the seller at expiration, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.

choices.itemBody: A. forward price plus the value of the underlying at expiration.
B. forward price minus the value of the underlying at expiration.
C. value of the underlying at expiration minus the forward price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Deriv-Teo-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following characteristics is most likely common to both forwards and swaps?

answerFeedback.3737ade3-7069-4352-9f42-315ae1358121: Correct because both forward contracts and swaps are traded over-the-counter (OTC), allowing the counterparties to negotiate and agree upon specific features for each contract. Exchange-traded derivatives are standardized, whereas OTC derivatives are customized. Further, a forward contract is an over-the-counter derivative contract.  Also, a swap is an over-the-counter derivative contract. Therefore, both forward contracts and swaps can be customized as they both are OTC derivative products.
answerFeedback.47f2765f-fa75-4e70-805d-f637378e6a60: Incorrect because it describes a characteristic of futures but not forward contracts or swaps. Probably the most important distinctive characteristic of futures contracts (compared to forwards and swaps) is the daily settlement of gains and losses and the associated credit guarantee provided by the exchange through its clearinghouse. In addition, at the end of each day, the clearinghouse engages in a practice called marked to market, also known as the daily settlement. The clearinghouse determines an average of the final futures trades of the day and designates that price as the settlement price. All contracts are then said to be marked to the settlement price. Therefore, both forwards and swaps are not marked to the settlement price on a daily basis.
answerFeedback.cb26d56a-210a-4f30-9b9b-0056c1564ccd: Incorrect because this describes a swap but not a forward contract. The concept of a swap is that two parties exchange (swap) a series of cash flows. Whereas in a forward contract the buyer will purchase an underlying asset from the other party, the seller, at a later date at a fixed price they agree on when the contract is signed.

choices.itemBody: B. Marked to the settlement price ​​​​​​on a daily basis
C. Multiple payments over the life of the contract

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Deriv-Beisswanger-02
entry.itemBody: A forward commitment:

answerFeedback.2336ea31-859e-4fe8-9844-3d5a928e3190: Correct because forwards, futures, and swaps represent firm commitments. Further, the symmetric payoff profile is a common feature of firm commitments. Since the derivative price is a linear function of the underlying, firm commitments are also referred to as linear derivatives.
answerFeedback.d0b9bbd0-43f7-4725-8afb-cacb2bded58c: Incorrect because as with futures and forward contracts, no money is exchanged when a swap contract is initiated. Also, forward commitments require no cash outlay at inception. Therefore, for forwards, futures, and swaps, no money is exchanged at contract initiation.
answerFeedback.ef32bf2d-2a23-46e4-9b1f-109d33176f99: Incorrect because forwards, futures, and swaps represent firm commitments, or derivative contracts that require counterparties to exchange an underlying in the future based on an agreed-on price. Also, forwards, futures, and swaps are the most common derivative contracts which represent a firm commitment. This firm commitment is an obligation of both counterparties to perform under the terms of the derivative contract. Therefore, forward commitments do not provide rights to the contract parties, they require the forward parties to exchange an underlying in the future based on an agreed-on price.

choices.itemBody: A. has a linear payoff in relation to the underlying.
B. involves an exchange of cash at contract initiation.
C. provides one party the right to transact at a later date.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Deriv-Gowen-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following types of derivatives has a non-linear payoff?

answerFeedback.ae713bdc-b967-4f60-8516-f2e9818b89c5: Correct because given that the holder of the contingent claim has a choice, the term contingent claim has become synonymous with the term option. The holder has a choice of whether or not to exercise the option. This choice creates a payoff that transforms the underlying payoff in a more pronounced manner than does a forward, futures, or swap. Those instruments provide linear payoffs: As the underlying goes up (down), the derivative gains (loses). The further up (down) the underlying goes, the more the derivative gains (loses). Options are different in that they limit losses in one direction.
answerFeedback.e7ad525c-ed68-4ef9-af03-23d5688d16be: Incorrect because given that the holder of the contingent claim has a choice, the term contingent claim has become synonymous with the term option. The holder has a choice of whether or not to exercise the option. This choice creates a payoff that transforms the underlying payoff in a more pronounced manner than does a forward, futures, or swap. Those instruments provide linear payoffs: As the underlying goes up (down), the derivative gains (loses). The further up (down) the underlying goes, the more the derivative gains (loses). Options are different in that they limit losses in one direction.
answerFeedback.ff9fe25e-5319-46d3-89d4-280e8563068e: Incorrect because given that the holder of the contingent claim has a choice, the term contingent claim has become synonymous with the term option. The holder has a choice of whether or not to exercise the option. This choice creates a payoff that transforms the underlying payoff in a more pronounced manner than does a forward, futures, or swap. Those instruments provide linear payoffs: As the underlying goes up (down), the derivative gains (loses). The further up (down) the underlying goes, the more the derivative gains (loses). Options are different in that they limit losses in one direction.

entry.body: Biomian Limited is a Mumbai-based biotech company with common stock and listed futures and options on the National Stock Exchange (NSE). The Viswan Family Office (VFO) currently owns 10,000 Biomian common shares. VFO would like to reduce its long Biomian position and diversify its equity market exposure but will delay a cash sale of shares for tax reasons for six months.
entry.title: Vignette
CFA2349-s07-Q4

feedback.neutral: C is correct. VFO may consider either a short futures position in (or a forward sale of) Biomian shares in six months to achieve its objective. This firm commitment allows VFO to offset its long position with a short position in six months at a pre-agreed price. The futures contract is an exchange-traded derivative with standardized terms set by the exchange and requires initial margin and daily settlement. Answers A and B are contingent claims that can both potentially increase, not decrease, VFO’s exposure to Biomian stock in six months.

entry.itemBody: Which of the following derivative contracts available to VFO’s chief investment officer is best suited to reduce exposure to a decline in Biomian’s stock price in the next six months?

choices.itemBody: A. A short put position on Biomian stock that expires in six months
B. A long call position on Biomian stock that expires in six months
C. A short futures position in Biomian stock that settles in six months

entry.title: CFA2349-s07-Q5

feedback.neutral: A is correct. VFO should purchase a six-month put option on Biomian shares to manage its exposure based on the market strategist’s view. This contingent claim grants VFO the right but not the obligation to sell Biomian shares at a pre-agreed exercise price in exchange for a premium. A put option buyer exercises the option at maturity when the underlying price is below the exercise price. This allows VFO to continue to benefit from a rise in Biomian’s share price over the next six months with a limited downside. Neither B nor C provides VFO with downside protection if Biomian stock declines in six months.

entry.itemBody: VFO’s market strategist believes that Biomian’s share price will rise over the next six months but would like to protect against a decline in Biomian’s share price over the period. Which of the following positions is best suited for VFO to manage its existing Biomian exposure based on this view?

choices.itemBody: A. A long put position on Biomian stock that expires in six months
B. A short call position on Biomian stock that expires in six months
C. A long futures position in Biomian stock that settles in six months

entry.title: CFA2349-s07-Q6

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Under a forward sale of Biomian shares, the profit is [F 0(T) – ST ]. If the shares rise significantly over the next six months—that is, ST > F 0(T)—then VFO’s loss on the derivative is the difference between the Biomian forward price, F 0(T), and the spot price, ST . Under the long put option on Biomian shares, VFO’s profit is max(0, X – ST ) – p 0. If Biomian shares rise significantly over the next six months (i.e., ST > X), then the option expires worthless and VFO’s loss is limited to the put premium paid, p 0. If [F 0(T) – ST ] > –p 0, then VFO’s loss would be greater under the firm commitment than under the contingent claim.

entry.itemBody: Assume that Biomian shares rise over the next six months. Which of the following statements about VFO’s derivative strategies under this scenario is most accurate?

choices.itemBody: A. A forward sale of Biomian shares in six months would be more profitable than purchasing the right to sell Biomian shares in six months.
B. Purchasing the right to sell Biomian shares in six months would be more profitable than a forward sale of Biomian shares in six months.
C. We do not have enough information to determine whether a forward sale or the right to sell Biomian shares will be more profitable in six months.

entry.title: CFA2349-s07-Q7

feedback.neutral: A is correct. The profit is equal to Π = max(0, ST – X) – c 0, and the payoff is equal to max(0, ST – X). The exercise price is INR16,000, and the spot price just prior to maturity is INR16,500, so Π = –1,000 [= (16,500 – 16,000) – 1,500], and the payoff is equal to INR500 [= (16,500 – 16,000)].

entry.itemBody: VFO’s market strategist is considering a six-month call option strategy on the NIFTY 50 benchmark Indian stock market index to increase broad market equity exposure. The NIFTY 50 price today is INR15,200, and the strategist observes that a call option with a INR16,000 exercise price (X) is trading at a premium of INR1,500. Which of the following represents the payoff and profit of this strategy just prior to maturity if the NIFTY 50 is trading at INR16,500?

choices.itemBody: A. Payoff is INR500; profit is –INR1,000.
B. Payoff is INR1,300; profit is INR800.
C. Payoff is INR1,300; profit is INR500.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601038
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements best describes a feature of an option contract? In an option contract:

answerFeedback.1662d087-c486-4873-b016-68c91617103a: Incorrect. Only the short can default. Beyond the initial payment of the premium, there is no further obligation for the long.
answerFeedback.e47833d6-7afd-4672-a9e1-9ca5b68bd463: Incorrect. Beyond the initial payment of the premium, there is no further obligation for the long.
answerFeedback.fb8b19a6-cfbe-4d78-bbf4-46f90b90d28a: Correct. Only the short can default. This scenario occurs when the long exercises the option and the short fails to fulfill its obligation under the contract.

choices.itemBody: C. both the long and the short can default.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Augulyte-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following derivatives most likely requires a payment to be made at the initiation of the contract? A(n):

answerFeedback.119d0cad-bfc3-48e5-a73a-a19e46498db3: Correct because an option is a derivative contract in which one party, the buyer, pays a sum of money to the other party, the seller or writer, and receives the right to either buy or sell an underlying asset at a fixed price either on a specific expiration date or at any time prior to the expiration date.
answerFeedback.426fc45d-b9fd-425c-85f6-d00b1aa83aea: Incorrect because as with futures and forwards, no money changes hands at the start; thus, the value of a swap when initiated must be zero.
answerFeedback.b3a300ce-caf8-488e-a481-dbb9c5239303: Incorrect because as with futures and forwards, no money changes hands at the start; thus, the value of a swap when initiated must be zero.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Klaschka-01
entry.itemBody: Counterparty default risk is most likely lowest for which of the following types of derivatives?

answerFeedback.692008d5-4aa6-459d-915f-0c630518af1e: Correct because exchange-traded derivatives (ETD) are standardized contracts traded on an organized exchange which requires collateral on deposit to protect against counterparty default and a futures contract is an exchange-traded derivative (ETD) with standardized terms set by the exchange. Therefore, futures has lowest counterparty default risk.
answerFeedback.d27d4035-102f-4679-ba69-df7233a0487f: Incorrect because a forward contract is an over-the-counter (OTC) derivative and OTC instruments have less transparency, usually involve more counterparty risk. Therefore, forwards do not have the lowest counterparty risk.
answerFeedback.f2742021-9d20-4796-8d79-f36b7dd37b20: Incorrect because swap credit terms are privately negotiated between counterparties in an over-the-counter agreement and may range from uncollateralized exposure, where each counterparty bears the full default risk of the other. Therefore, swaps do not have the lowest counterparty default risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Klaschka-06
entry.itemBody: Which party in an option contract has the right to sell the underlying stock at the exercise price?

answerFeedback.1eb57424-4392-4359-8684-48539d3bb8d4: Incorrect, because an option is a derivative contract in which one party, the buyer, pays a sum of money to the other party, the seller or writer, and receives the right to either buy or sell an underlying asset at a fixed price either on a specific expiration date or at any time prior to the expiration date. The right to buy is one type of option, referred to as a call or call option. The buyer of a call option has the right to buy the underlying stock.
answerFeedback.2ad19c5b-584a-43dc-8542-fa87c4fed027: Incorrect, because an option is a derivative contract in which one party, the buyer, pays a sum of money to the other party, the seller or writer, and receives the right to either buy or sell an underlying asset at a fixed price either on a specific expiration date or at any time prior to the expiration date. The right to sell is a (another) type of option, referred to as a put or put option. The seller of a put option has the obligation to buy the underlying if the buyer exercises the option.
answerFeedback.e372c350-c07b-49fa-864f-94d6159d659e: Correct, because an option is a derivative contract in which one party, the buyer, pays a sum of money to the other party, the seller or writer, and receives the right to either buy or sell an underlying asset at a fixed price either on a specific expiration date or at any time prior to the expiration date. The right to sell is a (another) type of option, referred to as a put or put option.

choices.itemBody: A. The buyer of a call option
B. The buyer of a put option
C. The seller of a put option

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Derivs-Agarwal-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most accurate?

answerFeedback.16f7bf5e-e093-4ae1-ae68-f3d154155320: Correct because a forward contract is an over-the-counter derivative contract in which two parties agree that one party, the buyer, will purchase an underlying asset from the other party, the seller, at a later date at a fixed price they agree on when the contract is signed.
answerFeedback.350b4f30-6a5f-454d-bac4-e48f5c5058da: Incorrect because it is actually the opposite and futures contracts are more transparent than forward contracts. Futures markets are far more transparent than forward markets.
answerFeedback.ab055ed1-15aa-41bd-8a4b-d7cbb25d0004: Incorrect because this is a characteristic of a futures contract and not a forward contract. A futures contract is a standardized derivative contract created and traded on a futures exchange in which two parties agree that one party, the buyer, will purchase an underlying asset from the other party, the seller, at a later date and at a price agreed on by the two parties when the contract is initiated and in which there is a daily settling of gains and losses and a credit guarantee by the futures exchange through its clearinghouse.

choices.itemBody: A. A forward contract is traded on an organized exchange.
B. Forward contracts are more transparent than futures contracts.
C. The buyer of a forward contract agrees to buy the underlying asset at a fixed price on a future date.

entry.title: ITEM_CopyofCFA-L1-08323
entry.itemBody: A trader sells a call option on a stock index with a strike price of 2,400 for $25. The value of a one-point move in the index is $1. At expiration, the stock index is trading at 2,450. The trader's profit is:

answerFeedback.c571254c-d631-4dcf-8336-2e774d20107d: Incorrect because $25 represents the profit to the buyer, not to the seller of the call option. The profit to a call buyer is defined as Max(0,ST – X) – c0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the value of the underlying at expiration and c0 is the call premium paid by the buyer. Therefore, Max(0,$2,450 – $2,400) – $25 = $50 – $25 = $25.
answerFeedback.d6540409-4d52-4f47-b4a6-b69c94de261f: Correct because the writer of a call is the seller of the call: An option is a derivative contract in which one party, the buyer, pays a sum of money to the other party, the seller or writer, and receives the right to either buy or sell an underlying asset at a fixed price either on a specific expiration date or at any time prior to the expiration date. The profit to the seller of the call is –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the value of the underlying at expiration and c0 is the call premium received by the seller. Since one point is equal to one dollar the profit to the call seller is: –Max(0,$2,450 – $2,400) + $25 = –$50 + $25 = –$25.
answerFeedback.fea10264-5e8a-4631-95b0-0958a979a913: Incorrect because this represents the value, not the profit, to the call seller, which is –Max(0,$2,450 – $2,400) = –$50, as described in the response rationale for the correct answer.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Tyler-03
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three portfolios each consisting of two derivatives on the same underlying:

  Forward Position Option Position
Portfolio 1 Long Long Call
Portfolio 2 Long Long Put
Portfolio 3 Short Long Call

All else being equal, which portfolio will benefit from an increase in price of the underlying?

answerFeedback.4e5aa416-3252-40eb-a485-ce071bb65f97: Incorrect because a contingent claim that benefits from a rise in the underlying price is the sold put option [not a bought put option].
answerFeedback.7d1cc61f-438e-4c3b-8cc5-10eabe0824f8: Incorrect because both a long forward position and a long [not short] call option position will gain from an increase in the underlying price.
answerFeedback.949c3aff-b99b-4929-b17f-f564c6039615: Correct because both a long forward position and a long call option position will gain from an increase in the underlying price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Bangaruswamy-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following derivatives have a non-linear payoff?

answerFeedback.7f7791d0-432d-4e9e-9182-bc84fb125299: Correct because asymmetric payoff profile is a common feature of contingent claims, which are sometimes referred to as non-linear derivatives.
answerFeedback.be125e4b-af36-442c-91c7-3affb24b8d7b: Incorrect because since the derivative price is a linear function of the underlying, firm forward commitments are also referred to as linear derivatives.
answerFeedback.fbde5dc0-ae0c-4004-aeb2-e8e739ece4b8: Incorrect because since the derivative price is a linear function of the underlying, firm forward commitments are also referred to as linear derivatives.

choices.itemBody: C. Both contingent claims and forward commitments

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Stroh-04
entry.itemBody: Consider a put option selling for $2 in which the exercise price is $45. What is the profit for a put buyer if the price of the underlying at expiration is $41?

answerFeedback.b6cac8e6-dbc1-4216-bf47-e46709bac0d6: Correct because the put’s value at expiration = pT = Max(0,X – ST), where pT is the value of the put at expiration, X is the exercise price, and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. In this case, Max(0,45 – 41) = $4. The put buyer’s profit = Π = pT – p0  (where p0 is the price of the put at time 0), or 4 – 2 = $2.
answerFeedback.c9ca2178-e080-40fa-873b-0d47dfbde8e5: Incorrect because this is the put seller's profit. The put’s value at expiration = –pT = –Max(0,X – ST), where pT is the value of the put at expiration, X is the exercise price, and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. In this case, –Max(0,45 – 41) = –$4. The put seller’s profit = Π = –pT + p0 (where p0 is the price of the put at time 0), or –4 + 2 = –$2.
answerFeedback.cf583519-992c-4181-8656-b3192e139def: Incorrect because this is the put's value at expiration. The put’s value at expiration = pT = Max(ST  – 0,X), where pT is the value of the put at expiration, X is the exercise price, and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. In this case, Max(0,45 – 41) = $4.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Eichenberger-03
entry.itemBody:
An investor collects the following information about a put option:

Stock price at initiation $220
Strike price $210
Option premium $9

At expiration, if the price of the stock is $200, the investor's profit from buying the put is:

answerFeedback.067256cc-3cf7-4e46-abfc-bd050c380ee1: Correct because Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0 (profit to the put buyer), where ST  is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price and p0 is the option premium. Therefore, the correct calculation yields: $1 = Max(0,$210 – $200) – $9.
answerFeedback.33f86c1e-7d27-406c-9dd9-392ff5c7aee5: Incorrect because the profit for the put buyer (Π) is not equal to ST – S0 + Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where S0 is the spot price of the underlying, ST  is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price and p0 is the option premium. Therefore, the incorrect calculation yields: –$19 = $200 – $220 + Max(0,$210 – $200) – $9, which includes the loss of $20 of the underlying. Instead, the correct formula is Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0 (profit to the put buyer) which yields: $1 = Max(0,$210 – $200) – $9.
answerFeedback.81e3c68b-8507-4bfa-9e72-dd1a781c351b: Incorrect because the profit for the put buyer is not equal to –p0, the option premium paid, or –$9, since the put option expires in the money. Instead, the correct formula is Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0 (profit to the put buyer), where ST  is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price and p0 is the option premium. Therefore, the correct calculation yields: $1 = Max(0,$210 – $200) – $9.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-Gosnell-Clone02ofCFA-L1-00096
entry.itemBody:
An investor sells a European put option with the following characteristics:

Put price 30
Exercise price 1,320

If the price of the underlying at expiration is 1,340, the profit for the seller is:

answerFeedback.8b57b444-36c2-4377-9a90-c54fefaf5b13: Correct because to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,320 – 1,340)) + 30 = 30.
answerFeedback.d882d1c4-7952-4d8a-b8d3-7adc1f00c39f: Incorrect because it represents the payoff to the call buyer cT = Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Therefore, cT = Max(0,(1,340 – 1,320)) = 20. By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,320 – 1,340)) + 30 = 30.
answerFeedback.fe015cd6-f32a-4e33-a133-c62081c481cc: Incorrect because it represents the put price p0 less the difference between the exercise price X and the price of the underlying ST at expiration: 30 – (1,340 – 1,320) = 10. This would be the profit to the seller of a call option, Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, with the same exercise price and the same selling price. By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,320 – 1,340)) + 30 = 30.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Augulyte-02
entry.itemBody: An investor buys a call option for $4 that has an exercise price of $27. At expiration, if the stock price is $22, the call option payoff is:

answerFeedback.61333239-2335-4ddf-ace1-3d59a32091ef: Correct because cT = Max(0,ST – X), where cT is the value of the call option, or the payoff to the call buyer, X is the strike (or exercise) price, and ST is the stock price at expiration. In this case, cT = Max(0,$22 – $27) = 0.
answerFeedback.9b3456dc-ad3a-4841-8958-693e2a546b95: Incorrect because it is the payoff to the put option buyer. That is, pT = Max(0,X – ST), where X is the strike (or exercise) price, and ST is the stock price at expiration. In this case, pT = Max(0,$27 – $22) = $5.
answerFeedback.ae2b0fd9-474a-4b55-af2c-da0cfaf2117b: Incorrect because it is the call buyer's profit, not the payoff. That is, Π = Max(0,ST – X) – c0, where c0 is the premium, ST is the stock price at expiration, and X is the strike (or exercise) price. In this case, Π = Max(0,$22 – $27) – $4 = –$4, and thus negative.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Eichenberger-02
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a call option:

Option premium $5
Exercise price $25
Price of the underlying at initiation $15

At expiration, if the price of the underlying is $30, the value of the call option to the call seller is:

answerFeedback.16f8b3c6-ad50-418c-b25d-c3b8a7c175df:
Incorrect because the call value at expiration for a call seller (–cT) is not –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price, and c0 is the option premium. Therefore, the incorrect calculation yields: $0 = –Max(0, $30 – $25) + $5, which is the profit for the call option seller.

Instead, the correct formula is –cT = –Max(0,ST – X) (payoff [value] to the call seller), which yields: –$5 = –Max(0,$30 – $25).
answerFeedback.6c12a43a-3641-4457-9ed1-43f64a6585e3: Correct because –cT = –Max(0,ST – X) (payoff to the call seller), where –cT is the call value at expiration for the call seller, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and X is the strike price. Therefore, the correct calculation yields: –$5 = –Max(0,$30 – $25).
answerFeedback.7832bb5a-48ac-47a4-bbfd-20e4b15cf5ea:
Incorrect because the call value at expiration for a call seller (–cT) is not Max(0,ST – X) + c0, where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, X is the strike price, and c0 is the option premium. Therefore, the incorrect calculation yields: $10 = Max(0, $30 – $25) + $5. 

Instead, the correct formula is –cT = –Max(0,ST – X) (payoff [value] to the call seller), which yields: –$5 = –Max(0,$30 – $25).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09159
entry.itemBody: An option is a type of a:

answerFeedback.74f29318-af1f-453d-8e97-4a749cc5e7f9: Incorrect because there are two general classes of derivatives. Some provide the ability to lock in a price at which one might buy or sell the underlying. Because they force the two parties to transact in the future at a previously agreed-on price, these instruments are called forward commitments. In contrast, an option provides the right but not the obligation to buy or sell the underlying at a pre-determined price.
answerFeedback.9f97e628-8ca3-420c-959a-1e91f5060c94: Incorrect because a swap is a type of a forward commitment, an option is not a type of a swap. The various types of forward commitments are called forward contracts, futures contracts, and swaps.
answerFeedback.fadb9e66-2f88-40d3-ba64-9f05332417b5: Correct because another class of derivatives provides the right but not the obligation to buy or sell the underlying at a pre-determined price. Because the choice of buying or selling versus doing nothing depends on a particular random outcome, these derivatives are called contingent claims. The primary contingent claim is called an option.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08006
entry.itemBody: The type of derivative that provides the right but not the obligation to buy an underlying is a:

answerFeedback.b8498a64-f37c-486c-9557-52daeaed1daf: Incorrect because the concept of a swap is that two parties exchange (swap) a series of cash flows. The similarities between futures and forwards apply to futures and swaps and, indeed, combinations of futures contracts expiring at different dates are often compared to swaps. Thus, as with a forward or a future, swaps do not give a holder the right but not the obligation to buy or sell an underlying.
answerFeedback.e3b2a345-6809-4e77-8ea6-dc60ae0a6a13: Correct because another class of derivatives provides the right but not the obligation to buy or sell the underlying at a pre-determined price. Because the choice of buying or selling versus doing nothing depends on a particular random outcome, these derivatives are called contingent claims. The primary contingent claim is called an option.
answerFeedback.f758ef1a-9ae6-4c67-a178-bc42b0a03bf5: Incorrect because some provide the ability to lock in a price at which one might buy or sell the underlying. Because they force the two parties to transact in the future at a previously agreed-on price, these instruments are called forward commitments. Thus forward commitments do not give the holder the right but the obligation to consummate the transaction at expiration.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07363
entry.itemBody: Which of the following types of derivatives most likely has a daily settling of gains and losses?

answerFeedback.221bec3b-ed1b-4939-be41-da4d6ac81eba: Incorrect because as with forward contracts, swap contracts also contain other terms—such as the identity of the underlying, the relevant payment dates, and the payment procedure—that are negotiated between the parties and written into the contract. Thus swaps, including currency swaps, mostly do not settle daily but have negotiated payment dates.
answerFeedback.9baecd27-8807-42f9-ab02-97d576647007: Incorrect because a forward contract is an over-the-counter derivative contract in which two parties agree that one party, the buyer, will purchase an underlying asset from the other party, the seller, at a later date at a fixed price they agree on when the contract is signed. Thus, a forward commitment is settled at the end of each agreed period and does not involve settlements related to daily mark-to-market values.
answerFeedback.9bfe5106-e505-47b0-9e75-7bec84f623e4: Correct because a futures contract is a standardized derivative contract in which there is a daily settling of gains and losses.
